times the original sample rate. By default, values beyond the boundary of the signal are assumed to be zero during the filtering step.
This polyphase method will likely be faster than the Fourier method in
when the number of samples is large and prime, or when the number of samples is large and
share a large greatest common denominator. The length of the FIR filter used will depend on

specifies the FIR low-pass filter design.

is an array_like it is assumed to be the FIR filter coefficients. Note that the FIR filter is applied after the upsampling step, so it should be designed to operate on a signal at a sampling frequency higher than the original by a factor of

. This function's output will be centered with respect to this array, so it is best to pass a symmetric filter with an odd number of samples if, as is usually the case, a zero-phase filter is desired.

By default, the end of the resampled data rises to meet the first sample of the next cycle for the FFT method, and gets closer to zero for the polyphase method:
This default behaviour can be changed by using the padtype option:
